title.narrative: PIMS 2979 Sustainable Land Management Pilot Project

description.narrative: PIMS 2979 Sustainable Land Management Pilot Project
Strategic Investment Programme (SIP) - Susistainable Land Management Pilot Project Eritrea.
capital of a political entity
populated place

activity-description.narrative:
Sub Region Serejeka ( Embadorho, Weki, Guritat,Dekseb, Hayelo......... Villages)
The project will create enabling environment (policy, capacity, knowledge, alternatives) necessary for adoption of Sustainable Land Management SLM) practices and alleviate environmental degradation while improving live

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative:
Maekel Region
1. Land distribution 2. Institution capacity building 3. Incentives for marginal lands 4. Income generating activities 5. Affirestation

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

To create the enabling environment (policy, capacity, knowledge, alternatives) necessary for adoption of sustainable LM practices and alleviate environmental degradation while improving livelihoods of the farming communities of the CHZ.

1. % decrease of degraded land area in Serejeka sub-zoba
-

comment.narrative:
Relevant baseline values to be established during inception phase; measure of current extent of land degradation will include, but will not be limited to:
- Land area (ha) of sub-zoba with signs of soil erosion
- Ha of land area deforested, using long-term time series
- Liters of water abstraction for agricultural use (irrigation) per ha (distribution map)
- Soil fertility levels (baselines to be established at pilot village level); relevant measures to be determined
- Level of NRM yields (e.g. crops)
Overall 25% decrease in degraded area; individual targets to be developed as per established measure during inception period

Total highly/severe degraded land was 16,180ha (Baseline).
Due to better land tenure system, introduction of land management, improved irrigation system and afforestation the degraded land relatively stabilised and reduced by 11% on crop lands and 12% on open access grazing land converted to community forest/woodlots.

description.narrative: 2. Ha of land under new (private) land tenure arrangements. No. of villages and area of land covered

comment.narrative: Currently the 1994 Land Proclamation is not applied and 0 ha of land in the Serejeka sub-zoba are under long-term private ownership/ tenure
More than 50% of land in the sub-zoba are under private title, following the provisions of the 1994 Land Proclamation
1,327.5 ha of agricultural land are put under the new (private) land tenure arrangements which belongs to 5 villages.

description.narrative: Decrease of population living below the poverty line in Serejeka sub-zoba

comment.narrative: Currently 66% of the population in Serejeka sub-zoba live below the poverty line (according to the international definition of poverty; assessed in xxx through xxx
The poverty rate is reduced to at least 40% in the sub-zoba

At this stage there is no concrete information/data available in poverty reduction, however, proxy estimates in the project area suggests that poverty has reduced slightly due to expansion of irrigation system by 60%, increase in agricultural production and other income generating interventions like horticulture, sale of vegetables from improved irrigation system and sale of timbers from afforestation interventions.
Overall 25% decrease in degraded area; individual targets to be developed as per established measure during inception period

description.narrative: Replicable models of SLM are developed and representative communities use them to manage land in 28 villages of the central highland that are representative of the major agro-ecological zone for central highlands, reducing the rate of land degradation
4. % Increase in land (ha) managed through community-level SLM plans

comment.narrative:
Currently no community-level SLM plans are in place
No of villages with functional SLM plans in place
Area (ha) managed through application of SLM plans
The management of land in Serejeka sub-zoba is guided by community level SLM plans (the Serejeka sub-zoba constitutes approximately 240,000 ha and 28 villages are situated in the sub-zoba)

No of villages with functional SLM plans in place: 5 villages out of 28 (5/28) which covers 18% of the total project area are in place with SLM plan.
Area (ha) managed through application of SLM plans: Total area covered is 1974ha ( Crop land 1005ha and community woodlots 970ha) this indicates 9% increment from baseline.

description.narrative: 5. Ratio of source of household incomes in the 28 pilot villages - income from agriculture versus other alternative income sources

comment.narrative: Baseline is established. Ratio of source of household incomes in the pilot villages i.e.; income from agriculture versus other alternative income sources follows the following pattern: 75% of the source of income is derived from agriculture while 25% comes from off farm employment and remittance.
Ratios clearly indicate income diversification (as a measure of resilience); final targets to be established during inception phase

No quantitative available data for this indicator, however, the proxy indicators shows that increased income generating activities such as bee keeping, expansion of woodlots and sale, cash income from dales of timber, expansion of irrigated crops (Vegetables) enhanced diversification of income sources and attributed to increase agricultural production.The proportion of source of household incomes in the pilot villages from agriculture versus other alternative income sources has shown slight shift from baseline situation. Estimated 5% increment is observed.

description.narrative: 6. No. of households in 28 pilot villages benefiting from application of Land Proclamation

comment.narrative: Currently the 1994 Land Proclamation is not applied and 0 households in the pilot area are currently benefiting from its application
More than 50% of rural/ land based households benefit from private tenure, following the provisions of the 1994 Land Proclamation

Land distribution is conducted in five villages and the zero baseline has increased by 23% which is 3313 HH out of 13223 households(HH)) has benefited from the new private land tenure system and sustainable land management practices.

description.narrative: A system of knowledge management (KM) for SLM is developed and used to achieve SLM through mainstreaming of SLM principles into the regional and national development programs, projects, strategies, policies and legislation
7. Increased knowledge about SLM practices amongst all project key stakeholders/ SLM platform members

comment.narrative: Knowledge baseline to be established during KCAS development during inception phase (Knowledge & Awareness survey amongst representative sample of key stakeholder groups)
50% of population in 28 pilot villages and 100% of all extension personnel reach knowledge and awareness target (set after baseline survey)

16960/53220 (32%) community members participated in sustainable land management awareness programmes in all 28 villages and 65% of extension personnel received trainings and acquired good knowledge and awareness of sustainable Land management principles. Besides practical and theoretical training on basic GPS application was conducted for 10 days. for 23 staffs from Ministry of Agriculture who are directly involved in the land distribution and mapping.

description.narrative: 8. Coordinated SLM KM â€œplatformâ€? operational and self sustaining

comment.narrative: No formal SLM-KM â€œplatformâ€? exists to date
A minimum of 7 SLM-KM â€œplatformsâ€? established (1 national, 3 regional and 3 sub-regional)
NO PROGRESS, however,continuous consultative meetings has been organised with community/village land distribution committee and sub zobas for smooth implementation of land distribution.

description.narrative: 9. Evidence of successful mainstreaming of SLM principles in key policies

comment.narrative: The existing draft land use policy does not integrate SLM principles and standards
SLM fully integrated (mainstreamed) into the new, approved land use policy
NO PROGRESS

description.narrative: 10. Zoba and sub-zoba annual budgets (in target area) include allocations for replication/adoption of SLM models to new villages and for the extension and implementation of SLM activities

comment.narrative: Baseline information on Zobas and sub zobas budget allocated to SLM practices will be determined during the inception phase
40 % increment on their budget for SLM practices

There is no quantitative data allocation of resources for SLM replication/adoption of SLM models. However, reports ( Secondary information) indicates that the government and the sub region invest on sustainable land management practices such as check dams, catchment treatment, afforestation and soil and water conservations. Sub region allocated 2-3 million ERN for the establishment of four nursery stations for tree seedling production to be distributed to communities in the project area. The nursery can produce over 1.2 million seedlings a year. Sub Zoba covers all related costs/expenses of production and transportation.

description.narrative: Capacity building programs and adaptive management systems are developed at all levels for improved governance of SLM, particularly enabling grass root community to implement improved SLM
11. % of annual increase in budget available for implementation of Capacity Support Strategy and Action plan (CSSAP) (in pilot area)

comment.narrative: Baseline value for CSSAP implementation to be determined during CSSAP
Annual increase of at least 15% (target value to be verified during baseline assessment) including from co-financing sources

Organisational system on forestry/ enclosures, water and irrigation, farm land management at village level has been developed. A draft bylaw has been prepared as working reference for the committee. Besides continuous training on SLM principles and applications has peen provided to all concerned committees.

description.narrative: 12. No. of individuals that apply the through the project developed extension packages

comment.narrative: No extension package available; baseline of people who apply packages is 0%

80% of all land managers in the 28 pilot villages use the packages; additionally more than 150 land managers in â€œreplicateâ€? areas do so; 100% of extension officers in Maekel zoba are knowledgeable about the extension packages and use them in their extension work

As an extension package improved seed varieties has already been distributed ( wheat, potatoes) also plant protection chemicals (pesticides/insecticides) supplied. Almost in all villages the natural resource conservation activities like terracing, afforestation, farm land terracing ...........,animal health service undertaken in the project area.

description.narrative: 13. Ratio of U$ leveraged through SLM relevant carbon finance project (s) and reinvestment into CCA activities in pilot area

comment.narrative: Currently no SLM relevant carbon finance project identified
At least one project identified, prepared and under implementation
No progress

description.narrative: Learning, evaluation, and adaptive management increased
14. Level of performance score achieved in scheduled evaluations

comment.narrative: Project design: to establish performance score (use GEF BD score as guidance)
A minimum of satisfactory performance (approx. 50% of all scheduled activities implemented to plan) at mid-term of project ; at least 90% at end of project
No progress.

description.narrative: Integrated Semenawi and Debubawi Bahri-Buri-Irrori- Hawakil Protected Area System for Conservation of Biodiversity and Mitigation of Land Degradation

The project goal is to ensure the integrity of Eritrea’s diverse ecosystems in order to secure the viability of the nation’s globally significant biodiversity through operationalization of Protected Areas Management System.

comment.narrative:

Marine: 0

Terrestrial: 649,100 ha
Marine: 360,000 ha

Terrestrial: 0
Marine: 0
So far no legal protected area policy and institutional framework to operationalize national protected area systems has been prepared thus no legally designated national protected area has been established as no regulatory framework has been prepared yet. Formulation of this regulatory framework is planned to be initiated in the fourth quarter of 2015 and consultation is under way to facilitate the process.
